I'd like to stroll with you now down the Ginza, the most
interesting part of downtown Tokyo. It is the heart of the
business section and is affectionately and officially known
as GINZA.
The crowds surging past the department stores, the staccato
pitch of traffic, the pell-mell pace of people running in
and out of shops, restaurants, bars, and hotels...this is
part of the Ginza. But, the couples walking slowly in
the dusk, the glittering neon signs, the night spots and
little coffee shops...this is part of Ginza, too. Add to
this the fortune tellers, the pin ball parlors, auction shops,
curio shops and hot spring hotels. For the Ginza is a place
of many moods and many activities. It is like the Loop in
Chicago, Union Square in San Francisco, and parts of Fifth
Avenue. Geographically located between the Tsukiji River
and the Outer Moat, Ginza has an amazingly small static
population of only 7 thousand people. But when morning
breaks, hordes of salaried workers, shoppers and sight¬
seers converge on the area and the Ginza population leaps to
half a million souls. Then, towards the evening, when the
brightly-colored neons shout their defiance at the gathering
dusk, the working crowds depart, leaving Ginza to the
nocturanal merrymakers. Later they too depart, leaving
Ginza deserted and forlorn with its little handful of
permanent residents.
At this time, Ginza is a vacuum when compared with its
surging life of the daylight hours.
